titleStmt.title: Will you have the walls
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably written between 1850 and 1855, when Whitman was preparing material for the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The ideas and language in the last section of the manuscript may relate to the first poem of that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself." The first part of this manuscript resembles a line in the fifth poem of that edition, eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric." The leaf looks like it may have been extracted from a notebook.

note.p: A phrase from this manuscript appeared in the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric": "Books, art, religion, time . . the visible and solid earth . . the atmosphere and the fringed clouds . . what was expected of heaven or feared of hell are now consumed" (1855, p. 79).

Language and ideas from this manuscript are similar to language and ideas in the first poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, ultimately titled "Song of Myself." See in particular: "And I know that the hand of God is the elderhand of my own, / And I know that the spirit of God is the eldest brother of my own" (1855, p. 15–16).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Will you have the walls [of] the world

On the back of this leaf are crossed-out prose notes.

revisionDesc.change: Corrected encoding, added corresps and work relation

body.ab: Will you have the walls the world with the air and the fringed clouds
body.l: The Poet says God and me
What do you want from us
Ask, and may be we give it you
body.ab: The Soul addresses God as his equal—as one who knows its greatness—as a younger brother
